statement.text: Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) is a chronic complication of DVT affecting 20-50% of patients, characterized by leg pain, swelling, heaviness, skin changes, and venous ulceration. It results from venous hypertension due to residual obstruction and/or valvular incompetence from thrombus-induced valve damage.
statement.formal: PTS: Chronic DVT complication (20-50%); Pathophysiology: venous HTN from obstruction + valve damage → reflux; Features: pain, edema, skin changes, ulcer; Villalta score for diagnosis/severity

explanation.intuition: When a blood clot forms in a vein, even after it dissolves, it often leaves behind scar tissue. This scar tissue can block the vein (like a partially clogged pipe) and destroy the one-way valves that keep blood flowing toward the heart. Without working valves, blood pools in the leg with gravity, causing chronic swelling, skin damage, and eventually ulcers.
explanation.key_insight: PTS is largely preventable or its severity reducible through adequate anticoagulation (preventing clot extension), compression (reducing venous pressure), and potentially early thrombus removal for iliofemoral DVT. Once established, PTS is chronic and management is symptom-focused.
explanation.technical_details: Thrombus resolution involves inflammation and fibrosis that damages venous valves. Valve destruction causes reflux; residual obstruction increases venous pressure. Ambulatory venous hypertension leads to capillary leak, inflammation, and tissue hypoxia. The Villalta scale (0-33 points) assesses 5 symptoms + 6 signs, with PTS defined as score ≥5 or presence of ulcer.

villalta_scale.scoring: Each item 0-3 (none, mild, moderate, severe); Total 0-33

diagnosis.clinical: Villalta score ≥5 at ≥3-6 months after DVT
diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Assess for reflux, residual obstruction, recanalization

prevention.compression: Graduated compression stockings (20-30 or 30-40 mmHg) - controversial benefit per SOX trial
prevention.early_ambulation: Encouraged; bed rest does NOT prevent PE
prevention.thrombus_removal: Catheter-directed therapy for iliofemoral DVT may reduce severe PTS

conservative.compression: Cornerstone of therapy - stockings or wraps
conservative.exercise: Calf muscle pump exercises, supervised exercise programs

interventional.venous_stenting: For chronic iliofemoral obstruction with symptoms refractory to conservative therapy
interventional.ulcer_management: Compression, wound care, possibly skin grafting

definition.@value: Chronic venous insufficiency following DVT, caused by residual obstruction and valve destruction

clinical_pearls: 20-50% of DVT patients develop PTS - it's common
Iliofemoral DVT has highest PTS risk - consider thrombus removal
Villalta score ≥5 diagnoses PTS; ≥15 or ulcer = severe
Compression is cornerstone of treatment (controversial for prevention)
Venous stenting for chronic iliac obstruction can dramatically improve symptoms
